awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Immunological adaptations in bats to moderate the effect of coronavirus infection
awd_abstract_narration:
All aspects of society have been upended by COVID-19. While most research has understandably focused on clinical applications, how the ancestors of SARS-CoV2 survive and circulate in nature is vital to both prevent future epidemics and help health professionals develop therapeutic treatments. Because some bat species are natural carriers of many coronaviruses, including the closest known relatives of SARS-CoV-2, the team supported by this award will identify consistent differences between bats and other mammals likely involved in moderating infection by regulating virus entry and mounting an effective immune response. This project will address how bats escape illness despite carrying a wide range of viruses. As part of this work, the research team will develop educational displays related to the bat immunology for public display at the Museum of Texas Tech. Results for the study will also be published in peer-reviewed journals, presented at scientific meetings, and posted to shared data repositories.

Researchers supported by this award hypothesize there are consistent differences in the genes involved in the immune response pathways of bats compared to other mammals, such that: a) bats show disproportionate numbers of unique genomic adaptations; b) there is higher expression of immune system genes in bats than in comparable mouse and human tissues, and c) expression of genes involved in coronavirus cell entry in bats differs in RNA profile, limiting the extent pathogenesis when compared to humans and mice. To test these hypotheses, the team will analyze genome structure across diverse bats species, and differential expression analysis of different tissues, in the context of viral tropism and immune response. Resulting data will inform researchers and clinicians as they anticipate and treat these respiratory syndromes. This RAPID award is made by the Physiological and Structural Systems Cluster in the BIO Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

COVID-19 has impacted all aspects of our society. Our project identified consistent differences among bats and between bats and other mammals that are likely involved in mediating viral entry and immune response. This information can inform clinicians with regard to prevention or therapeutics and is vital. Conducting this systematic analysis of the structure and function of the immune responses of bats provided research targets. 

The project consisted of three major objectives:

1) Generate and analyze high-quality genome assemblies to identify the immunogenetic repertoire as well as species-specific adaptations in bats, and compare them to those in other mammals, including humans and mice. 

2) Combine whole genome analyses with transcriptomic data to discover how baseline (i.e., putatively healthy) immune systems express genes differently in bats and well-studied models such as humans and mice. Identification of differences in RNA expression across immune system genes from diverse tissues may help explain how the trajectory of bat viral exposure differs from that of other mammals.

3) Build and test an integrated immune/receptor model of bat gene expression across diverse tissues. Using published expression data available primarily from animal models, as well as currently unpublished data from bats, we will test this model.

Objective 1 is complete. We sequenced high-quality genome assemblies for four bat species. We annotated >35 bats genomes and performed comparative genome analyses including gene family evolution, gene loss detection, and selection analyses between bats and six non-bat mammals as outgroups to analyze the immune repertoires of Chiroptera and compared with outgroup mammals.

In addition, we made a whole genome alignment, including >35 bat genomes, that will be used to achieve new objectives derived from our results obtained from objective 1.

Objective 2 is partially complete. Without biological replicates, between-species transcriptome data took some time, but we now have a full pipeline culminating in Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models of gene expression evolution and finding differential expression in key genes.

Objective 3 is in progress. While our genomic model has been submitted for publication, validation is proceeding with expression data.

Broader Impacts: The COVID-19 pandemic was a hindrance to some objectives associated with this project but we were still able to implement most activities. With the closing of schools, we shifted our efforts in educating high school teachers to undergraduates in our respective courses and laboratories. Dr. Ray incorporated four undergraduate students in efforts to examine genome structure and gene family evolution in bats in comparison to other mammals. In addition, the genome assemblies generated by this project were actively used as part of two courses. Dr. Davalos incorporated four graduate students into the project, all of whom were mentored in genomics techniques. Two of the students designed and conducted internships to make genomics tools accessible to all. The results of those internships directly link this project to the general public and provide scalable educational tools.

Finally, the award was used to support multiple additional publications and presentations, including Thus far these awards have supported work associated with eleven publications [1-5] including two in Nature [6, 7] and one in Molecular Ecology [8]. Three additional publications associated with the project are under review at high-impact journals [9-11], and one has been accepted. Persons associated with the work and analyses delivered eight seminars or lectures at a variety of local and international venues.

 

1.         Yohe, L.R., et al., Diversity in olfactory receptor repertoires is associated with dietary specialization in a genus of frugivorous bat. G3 Genes|Genomes|Genetics, 2021. 11(10): p. jkab260.

2.         Korstian, J.M., et al., SINE-Based Phylogenomics Reveal Extensive Introgression and Incomplete Lineage Sorting in Myotis. Genes, 2022. 13(3).

3.         Ghosh, A., et al., A High-Quality Reference Genome Assembly of the Saltwater Crocodile, Crocodylus porosus, Reveals Patterns of Selection in Crocodylidae. Genome Biol Evol, 2020. 12(1): p. 3635-3646.

4.         Vandewege, M.W., et al., The PIWI/piRNA response is relaxed in a rodent that lacks mobilizing transposable elements. RNA, 2022. 28(4): p. 609-621.

5.         Ghosh, A., et al., Identification and characterization of microRNAs (miRNAs) and their transposable element origins in the saltwater crocodile, Crocodylus porosus. Anal Biochem, 2020. 602: p. 113781.

6.         Jebb, D., et al., Six reference-quality genomes reveal evolution of bat adaptations. Nature, 2020. 583(7817): p. 578-584.

7.         Genereux, D.P., et al., A comparative genomics multitool for scientific discovery and conservation. Nature, 2020. 587(7833): p. 240-245.

8.         Moreno Santillan, D.D., et al., Large-scale genome sampling reveals unique immunity and metabolic adaptations in bats. Mol Ecol, 2021. 30(23): p. 6449-6467.

9.         Zoonomia, C., Evolutionary constraint and innovation across hundreds of placental mammals. Science, Submitted.

10.       Paulat, N.S., et al., Chiropterans are a hotspot for horizontal transfer of DNA transposons in Mammalia. Science, Submitted.

11.       Osmanski, A.B., et al., Insights into mammalian TE diversity via the curation of 200+ mammalian genome assemblies. Science, Submitted.
